message.content: A merism is a figure of speech in which certain parts of a whole are emphasized by using an expression that suggests only a part, rather than the whole, is being referred to. Merisms typically involve contrasting or complementary elements and create a vivid image in the reader's mind. Examples of merisms include "the tip of the iceberg" (suggesting there is much more beneath the surface), "a drop in the ocean" (implying an insignificant amount compared to the whole), or "barking up the wrong tree" (meaning pursuing the wrong course of action).
